bibl.title: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, September 20, 1950

div1.p: Ames comments on the recent deaths of Emilie Lawrence Reed and Kean. She thinks it would be better to exhibit the yellow fever materials at the Mayo Clinic rather than in Charlottesville.

div1.head: Letter from Jessie Daniel Ames to Philip Showalter Hench, September 20, 1950

opener.dateline:
THE WREN'S NEST
TRYON, NORTH CAROLINA
20 September, 1950

div1.p:
I had seen the story of Mrs. Reed's death in the New York TIMES
and now I see in the last issue of TIME that General Kean is al-
so dead.

I am inclined to think that if you place the exhibits of the Yel-
low Fever work in Cuba at the Mayo Clinic it would serve a larger
public than if it were at Charlottesville. Public service rather
than sentiment should be the deciding factor.

Since it is not wise to follow through on your original plan of
establishing a museum in Cuba at the place where the camp was
set up, would it be possible to have a replica of the buildings
and the topography made for the exhibits where ever they may be
placed? I am sure you have some pictures or descriptions of the
place to create an appearance of reality. After fifty years there
cannot be many, if any, who could point out mistakes in the re-
production.

I don't know that this suggestion that I am going to make is pos-
sible. If it is, then you are the one who can follow it, if it
appeals to you as worthwhile.

It seems to me that all the data on this work in Cuba could be
gathered to-gether and placed in one grouping in the National
Archives. With the unification of the armed forces an accomplished
face, on the surface anyway, it seems reasonable to proceed to a
unification of the records of the armed services. Who knows but
that in another fifty years, if we are still a democracy and grad-
uate students still write theses on long forgotten subjects, the
University of Virginia might inspire some graduate student to do
his thesis on Major Reed. From your description of the diffusion
of the records in the National Archives, the going would be too
overwhelmingly difficult.
